comments.commentBody: Also thanks Kiki.  I've often had problems about what I might want to buy, or how I should cook/otherwise prepare it, because my greengrocers spell things in ways that I couldn't quite decipher.

The Afghan government survived for three years after the Soviets withdrew.  It was America's most important non-NATO ally, Pakistan (remember, that is what the US used to call Pakistan?) that helped put the kibosh on that.  The fact is that the Soviet-backed government in Afghanistan was modernist, and the US aided the most regressive mujahideen.   For all his brutality, Saddam Hussein was modernist and secular - and in retrospect seems to be a lamb compared the Islamists.

There's a fair amount of contemporary evidence that male dominance behavior and sexuality are intertwined. Look at the behavior of our closest cousin, the bonobo. The behavior of prisoners and British boarding school students is pretty much the same. It comes out in our language, in statements like "- you" and "I've been -ed." In short, aggressive, penetrative homosexual behavior is our distant ancestors' means of expressing dominance, and while we suppress those instincts they are still present to some degree.

Clinton has the same energy as the Roosevelts - TR and FDR. And that's where it's at. The energy exhibited or shall I say exhaled by charisma is significant. While I can easily criticize him for several errors nonetheless his presidency saw something done in DC. Maybe that is what we need. Can charisma actually get congre$$men to earn their pay?
Uh, yes you do when it is the entire institution that is rotten, when the horrors are systemic.

Driving and flying and many other activities following your ellipsis are essential functions in society, unlike football. Educational institutions at all levels should end their involvement with contact sports and parents who allow participation after multiple concussions occur should be investigated for child endangerment.

The difference is that an MVA caused injury requires law enforcement to be involved, allowing us a pretty good handle on actual numbers/occurrences.  You know that we have no idea how often this is happening and no one knows about it.  Penn State, Florida A & M--those are just some recent big events.  This is the tip of the iceberg.
Football ended long ago as a sport.  It now exists only as a business........
Someone should organize a March to End Football.

Ken, you are probably right but I would suggest those thousands that turned out to be good citizens most likely would have without football.  Problem is none of us should accept these actions at any level and football is now getting the focus as it should.  I loved playing basketball in HS and there was towel snapping and stuff in the locker room.  I wasn't a big kid and I didn't like it then.  I never imagined the things that happened in that NJ locker room would happen, let alone be condoned.  Some kids did that in my small HS they would've been shaped up in the alley by someone bigger and tougher.  Not by me of course, I wasn't big enough, but I sure liked to see bullies get their due.  The guys doing the shaping up were not bullies.  They stood up to them.

I disagree with the last. For one thing, anal penetration hurts. For another, it appears to be our primitive instinctive means of expressing pecking-order dominance (see the behavior of our closest relative the bonobo). Thus it has a different psychological significance than other forms of touching. In any case, even cultures in which homosexual behavior was sanctioned and widely practiced recognized the difference between consensual and non-consensual anal penetration. It's akin to the difference between consensual and non-consensual vaginal penetration.
You are intelligent and sensitive, and you read. One recommends to you the "delightful" prospective advantage of living in a state not blighted by Ohio politics.

Why is it whenever somebody points out the failure of fiscal policy to work in the 1930s, the argument shifts to the supposed success of WWII spending?  WWII was a period of much greater hardship and scarcity for the world than the depression period, regardless of the nominal GDP associated with the largest waste of resources and wealth destruction in the history of mankind.

Wow, man in his 40's having his first child yammering on about how others are rejecting adulthood?  What is stunning is that the same arguement could be made against this guy. What exactly was he doing whilst all his friends were hunkering down and raising children?  Rejecting adulthood maybe?
So when Mr. Shaftel was able to have brunch on a regular basis, brunch was great. But now that he can't, brunch is clearly for jerks.
In other words, "I have a kid now and I resent people who still have free time and fun on weekends."

Whoever is blaming the author for having a child and being resentful about people who brunch is completely missing the point.  I am childless and maybe even in the demographic of the people who do these boozy brunches and #sundayfunday (although I have only participated a handful of times).  Then I realized I'd rather eat cereal at home, clean my room, take a walk in nature, help my mother do errands, and I don't know....not spend $45 on horrible pancakes and strawberry butter.  It's fine to do this once in a while but every weekend?  For the most over-rated food ever!  The author's point is that once he got a child he realized he has responsibilities and maybe some of us should do that too.  How about going home to be with our parents or relatives because Sundays are the only days they have free from work and want to spend time with us?  How about community service? Or saving for travel, for retirement, for education, or literally anything else? I now simply refuse to spend so much money and time on one stupid meal where all everyone does is talk about one another.
I don't know. Usually this stuff goes unpunished when boys are the victims as well.

Japan was the first Keynesian. In 1932 their Minister of Finance (MoF) devalued the yen and implemented a vast govt spending program (armaments). The devaluation helped textile exporters replacing British in foreign markets. Jap was out of the depression by 33. By 34 the MoF moved to end stimulus but was assassinated by militarist who wanted the arms build up to continue. By 39 Japan's industrial GNP was 100% above 1929 and transformed from textiles to heavy industry emphasis.

In June 1934 the Nazi's ended make work programs opting for full bore armaments drive. By 1940 German GNP was 139% above 1929 (1929 Ger made 90,000 cars vs 250,000 for UK and Fr ea. and 5 million in U.S)

Chamberlain as Chancellor of the Exchequer would over see both UK's & US's econ recovery. In early 30s he stimulated domestic economy through a major housing program and 10% tariff (today Jap averages 9%) Imperial preference policy.

Total adult employment in US remained below the 1929 levels into early 41! (while working pop had grown) The recovery began in 1938 but not so much from US re-armament, because isolationism was still strong, but from armaments contracts from UK and France through to very late 1940 & 41. Only the fall of France truly shocked US into armaments drive. The 14 million who went into work force or Armed forces after 1940 was taken from the still unemployed labor slack.

Jan 2009 S. Korea implemented a stimulus=25% of GNP over 4 years. By 2010 GNP up 6%, 3% unemployed.

Sorry.
God forbid people might actually like to spend their day off relaxing, get a late start, share a leisurely meal with friends. Who do they think they are, the French?

I am not sure what disturbs the author most: Is it the increasing inequality & disappearance of the urban middle class or the disappearance of family friendly restaurants and the good old family traditions in general? If it is the first, then I agree - and you have the same tendencies not only in NYC but also in all European capitals. But if it is the second, then the same arguments sound odd: One can be tired of the brunch-fashion and all that it symbolizes, but not really eager to return to the 50s life style...

"At 2:00 in the afternoon on Sunday, my favorite French place won't serve me steak frites; they only offer steak and eggs with a 2 ounce steak and home fries."  This is what is known as a first world problem.  Get over it!  People who are actually subject to the economic disparities which the authors decries don't have time to sit around and pontificate about how brunch is ruining their lives.  This is a privilege enjoyed by those who are paid to write drivel for the new York Times and to their primary demographic of readership who claim to care about economic disparities and lack of diversity but, who are really just mad that they can't get what they want for lunch on Sunday at 2:00.

"Capital cannot rule over trade balances".....but it will, it has, as it has always been in history.
Private capital , being portable, transferable, historically supercedes regulation, politics, wars, peacetime, revolutions any morality or philosophy.
In human nature, Greed is the God of Survival.
So much for Instinct...

'2) A condition of consolidating under the Euro could have been forcing trade balance. That is, preventing Germany from running a surplus against the periphery.'

Very funny!

You mean - 'That is, preventing the periphery from running a plus against Germany.

This isn't just about the balance of trade, it is about the balance of credit. Yes, POC, not only do we need to balance trade but we need to prevent the fiscal loaning of money on balance across borders.

Surplus caused by credit doesn't count. Those loans should be prevented in the first place.

Europe could have avoided this 2 ways:

1) They should not have consolidated under the Euro

OR:

2) A condition of consolidating under the Euro could have been forcing trade balance. That is, preventing Germany from running a surplus against the periphery.

Forcing this balance would have required some creativity in policy. Europe is different than the China/US trade imbalance in that the country that was running the biggest surplus was also a country with well paid workers.

In reading back over some of the monetary theory of the past, there's some really naive assumptions, such as capital flows that accompany trade imbalances are helpful over the long run to develop higher productivity, and that over time there is a point where these imbalances work themselves out.

Well, it should be obvious that this is wrong and it always was wrong. Don't tell anyone though, because it might upset the rich investors of the world. Being rich isn't enough for them. They also must be coddled and made to feel like their money is a godsend to those they exploit.

They could keep the Euro if they would make some adjustments and just buy up the debt, but it would be foolish to do so without first putting in place a forced trade balance. Rather than moralizing this, they should be thinking of long-term policy solutions. The entire economics profession is in a deep, deep denial about capital.

Capital cannot rule over trade balances.

Okay, Will.  You're invited Chez widow Rose at 86.  Show up if not engaged, next Sunday at 1:00 p.m. at 424  E. 12th street, 5th floor, NY (attire optional).  Walk up if the elevator is out of order again and ignore the invisible super who is in hazy stupor.  Just bring yourself and a copy of the Sunday Times.  If you don't eat bacon or ham, let me know, including if you have any food allergies.  It's two eggs Pope Benédict on an English muffin with sauce Hollandaise, instant coffee or Irish morning tea, with a ginger-ale mimosa in a flute glass, or a virgin Mary with a crisp celery stalk, for the pleasure of your company.  If you tell a good story, you will get ice-cream and a few little brownies for dessert, and undivided attention.  Let me know!
Shorter version:  I have a child now so I have to be an adult, but other people are still acting like college kids.  Unfair!

I would like to point out that it was easier to gather congressional votes before we outlawed pork spending. Members of Congress have no desire to vote for something they're against and get nothing in return. For all the negatives surrounding pork spending, it helped grease the wheels of Washington so deals could be brokered. That's no longer the case.

AGREED. It will still take several more generations to see a more structural change. People change and that affects people in power and that affects how the law is applied. sad but true.but it is coming.

You criticize Mr. Shaftel's escape from brunch, give ungenerous advice which is not your business to give and does not fairly arise from the substance of his writing yet brag about your excellent neighborhood's letting you escape from brunch.
